RESUMO-CV.TEXTO-RESUMO-CV-RH:
In April 2014, Dr. Salvatore Bongarzone joined the group of Prof. Tony Gee and Prof. Federico E. Turkheimer at King's College of London. He focuses on the use of PET imaging in drug discovery and development.
In November 2013, Salvatore completed a Postdoctoral research fellowship at IRB (Institute of Research in Biomedicine, Barcelona, Spain), supported by EU MarieCurie Actions, under the supervision of Prof. F. Albericio and Prof. M. Coll. During this period, he carried out design, synthesis and characterization of antiviral compounds binding a viral enzyme. Lead compounds have been derived from the identification of a starting fragment able to interact with the active site of the viral enzyme. He also handled the crystallization and 3D structure determination of the protein-inhibitor complex by X-ray crystallography.
In October 2011, Salvatore received a PhD in Physics and Chemistry of Biological Systems (International School of Advanced Studies, SISSA/ISAS, Trieste, Italy) under the supervision of Profs P. Carloni, G. Legname and M. L. Bolognesi. During his doctoral studies, he gained an interdisciplinary knowledge ranging from organic synthesis to computational chemistry devoted to discover ligand starting with the selection of two substructures interfering with two distinct pathological targets or events responsible in the pathogenesis of prion diseases. Then the molecular fragments have been joined by a chemical linker leading to a multitarget ligand able to act simultaneously on multiple fronts: by blocking the abnormal conversion of the prion protein, by reducing oxidative stress and by chelating metal ions.
In March 2007, Salvatore majored in pharmaceutical chemistry (110 cum laude) at the University of Bologna with a plan to enter in the drug discovery field. During his thesis under the supervision of Profs. M.L. Bolognesi and A. Cavalli, he became particularly interested in medicinal chemistry.
